item.title: Aligning many sequences quickly
item.description: Speeding things up The topics we discussed in the past lecture explain fundamental concepts behind analysis of biological sequences. Today, we will be talking about algorithms that allow aligning billions of sequencing reads against reference genomes.

item.title: Sequence alignment: Introductory concepts
item.description: The cover image shows pairwise alignments for human, mouse, and dog KIF3 locus from Dubchak et al. 2000. Introduction to dynamic programming (Based on dynamic programming example from InteractivePython).

item.title: Assembly basics
item.description: Genome assembly is a difficult task. In trying to explain it I will be relying on two highly regarded sources: Ben Langmead’s Teaching Materials Pevzner and Compeau Bioinformatics Book.

item.title: DNA Sequencing: PabBio, ONT and others
item.description: PacBio Single Molecule Sequencing PacBio is a fundamentally different approach to DNA sequencing as it allows reading single molecules. Thus it is an example is so called Single Molecule Sequencing or SMS.

item.title: DNA Sequencing: Illumina
item.description: A few classical papers to start In a series of now classical papersp Philip Green and co-workers has developed a quantitative framework for the analysis of data generated by automated DNA sequencers.

item.title: DNA Sequencing: From Sanger to 454
item.description: The 50s, 60s and the 70s The difficulty with sequencing nucleic acids is nicely summarized by Hutchinson:2007: The chemical properties of different DNA molecules were so similar that it appeared difficult to separate them.

item.title: History
item.description: Why history? Knowing history is essential for understanding how we arrived to the current state of affairs in our field. It is also full of accidental discoveries and dramatic relationships making it quite interesting to read about.
